The order Judgment and decree of SeSir George Snygge Knight one of his Maties Maiesties Barons of his Exchquer, Thomas Yonge of the Cittye of Bristoll Esquier
Israell Gleson of the same Citty Bachelor Bachelor of lawe and of John Younge of Clifton in the County of Gloucester gentleman fower of the Comissiomers named in the Comission hereunto annexed
taken and made at the saide Citty of Bristoll after the Inquisicion hereunto annexed taken and founde for the due and faithfull imploying of the landes tenementes Rentes hereditamentes
and profittes specified and declared and founde ffor that it appeareth planely unto us by the said Inquisicion any by recordes and other evdences that the lande tenementes and hereditamentes
in the Countyes of Somerset Gloucester and Bristoll in the said Inquisicion and schedule mencioned were by the good devotion charity, trabell trouble?, charge and expences of SeSir Thomas West Knight Lord
Laware, George Crofte Clerk, Robert Thorne of London Merchaunt, Nicholas Thorne Alderman of the same Cittye of Bristoll, and John Goodriche Clerke Executor Executor of the testament and last will
of Robert Thorne sometyme of Bristoll Merchaun deceased father of the saide Nichola[s] provided, givenm assured and conveyed for the maintenance of a free Schoole of one Schoole Maister and of one or more
ushers and of the bringing up of children and yowthe in the feare of God for ever [with]in the saide Citty of Bristoll comonly to be called the Bartholomewe Schoole Wee are fully satisfied by the
saide Inquisicion Recordes evidences and hearing of every of the parties clayming any interest therein That the same was efectually established to that end and purpose to have had continuance for ever
But for that the saide landes tenementes and hereditamentes in the said Inquisicion and Schedule mentioned discended and came ( as it was pretended ) to Nicholas Thorne of the said Citty of Bristoll
Merchaunt as to the lawfull heire of Robert Thorne his brother and of the said Nicholas Thorne his father or one of them, he the said Nicholas Thorne the sonne by ?color thereof uniustly procured
A conveyance in the fee fearme under the yerely rent of Thirtie Poundes onelt from the MaiorMaior Burgesses and Commaltye of the saide Citty to the defrauding of the true intencion of imployment of the saide
landes tenementes and hereditamentes and of the profittes thereof And afterwardes he the saide Nicholas Thorne the sonne being chosen and made Chamberlen of the saide Citty of Bristoll and thereby having
accesse unto the places where the Recordes and Evidences of the saide landes tenementes hereditamentes remayned did under pretext of the graunt of the saide fee fearme esloigne assign take and convey away
most or the cheifest parte of the materiall evidences recordes or writ[in]ges concerning the same And hath made [?and] contrived divers and sundery estates and interestes to divers and sundrye personns
resppectively every of the them knowing of the saide trust and confidence in the fee farme and leases for lives and yeres to the decaye of the saide Schoole, Schoolemr Schoolemaster, and other the said uses. Wee therefore having long endeavoured to appease the same person and personns and every of them And to have taken away all and singuler ?stimples doubtes ambiguities and misimploymentes And having
hearde every of the saide parties interessed (they and every of then obstinately refusing to conforme them selves to such reasonable ?caurses as equity is in orour opinions requireth ) Doe thinke fitt that the saide landes tenementes and hereditamentes be returned to the saide true furst use and intent of imployment thereof That such saide Schoole Mr Master Usher Ushers and Instructer of the
saide children and youthe maie the better hereafter live of the profittes and Revenues of the saide landes, Wch Which nowe they cannot doe, And that children maie be the better instructed in Ã¾e the
saide Schoole And in the feare and knowledge of God
Doe order adiudge and decree ( whereas the profittes of the saide landes and tenementes by pretext of the saide fee fearme
graunted as aforesaide have bene only thirtie poundes yerely viz Twenty Poundes to the Schoole Mr Master and tenn poundes to the Usher (nothing aunswerable to their paines travell reliefe or
maintenance ) That the Schoole Mr Master should have yerely the yerely wages of fforty Poundes And the Usher or Usherss Twenty Poundes WchWhich wages wilbe raysed of the yerely profittes of the
saide landes and tenementes uiust encombrances being discharged ) over and above the dwelling houses of the saide Schoole Mr Master and usher In witnes wherof wee the aforesaide
fower Comissioners have unto this orour presente order and decree putt orour handes and seales the Six and Twenty daie of Aprill in the yeres of the Reigne of or our Sovereigne Lord James by the
grace of God King of England Scotland ffraunce and Irelande defender of the faith etc viz of England ffraunce and Ireland the Seaventh And of Scotland the xlijti
[Signed by Sir George Snygge, Thomas Younge, Israell Gleson and John Younge. The seals are no longer attached.]
